questiontext.text:
A farm produces 4 types of fruit: coconuts, watermelons, papayas, and bananas. The fruits’ masses follow normal distributions, with parameters dependent on the type of fruit.

Type of fruit _ _ Mean mass (g) _ _ Standard deviation of mass (g) _
coconuts 492 34
watermelons 8042 1292
papayas 487 38
bananas 222 21

One specimen of each type is weighed. The results are shown below.

specimen type _ _ Mass of specimen (g)
coconut 439
watermelon 10550
papaya 482.8
banana 239.8
  1. Calculate a zz score for the coconut specimen. (Round to the nearest hundredth.) {1:NUMERICAL:=-1.56:0.011}
  2. What percent of coconuts have less mass than the coconut specimen? {1:NUMERICAL:=0.0594:0.004}
  3. Calculate a zz score for the watermelon specimen. (Round to the nearest hundredth.) {1:NUMERICAL:=1.94:0.011}
  4. What percent of watermelons have less mass than the watermelon specimen? {1:NUMERICAL:=0.9738:0.004}
  5. Calculate a zz score for the papaya specimen. (Round to the nearest hundredth.) {1:NUMERICAL:=-0.11:0.011}
  6. What percent of papayas have less mass than the papaya specimen? {1:NUMERICAL:=0.4562:0.004}
  7. Calculate a zz score for the banana specimen. (Round to the nearest hundredth.) {1:NUMERICAL:=0.85:0.011}
  8. What percent of bananas have less mass than the banana specimen? {1:NUMERICAL:=0.8023:0.004}
  9. {1:MULTICHOICE:%0%The coconut specimen is most unusually large.~%100%The watermelon specimen is most unusually large.~%0%The papaya specimen is most unusually large.~%0%The banana specimen is most unusually large.}
  10. {1:MULTICHOICE:%100%The coconut specimen is most unusually small.~%0%The watermelon specimen is most unusually small.~%0%The papaya specimen is most unusually small.~%0%The banana specimen is most unusually small.}
  11. {1:MULTICHOICE:%0%The coconut specimen is most typically sized.~%0%The watermelon specimen is most typically sized.~%100%The papaya specimen is most typically sized.~%0%The banana specimen is most typically sized.}
  12. {1:MULTICHOICE:%0%The coconut specimen is most unusually sized.~%100%The watermelon specimen is most unusually sized.~%0%The papaya specimen is most unusually sized.~%0%The banana specimen is most unusually sized.}

generalfeedback.text:
1. We use the formula for calculating the coconut specimen’s zz score. z=439−49234=−1.56z = \frac{439-492}{34} = -1.56
  2. Use the zz table to find the percentile rank. P(Z<−1.56)=0.0594P(Z<-1.56) = 0.0594
  3. We use the formula for calculating the watermelon specimen’s zz score. z=10550−80421292=1.94z = \frac{10550-8042}{1292} = 1.94
  4. Use the zz table to find the percentile rank. P(Z<1.94)=0.9738P(Z<1.94) = 0.9738
  5. We use the formula for calculating the papaya specimen’s zz score. z=482.8−48738=−0.11z = \frac{482.8-487}{38} = -0.11
  6. Use the zz table to find the percentile rank. P(Z<−0.11)=0.4562P(Z<-0.11) = 0.4562
  7. We use the formula for calculating the banana specimen’s zz score. z=239.8−22221=0.85z = \frac{239.8-222}{21} = 0.85
  8. Use the zz table to find the percentile rank. P(Z<0.85)=0.8023P(Z<0.85) = 0.8023
  9. We determine the maximum zz score is 1.941.94, which belongs to the watermelon. / . / . / .
  10. We determine the minimum zz score is −1.56-1.56, which belongs to the coconut. / . / . / .
  11. We determine the minimum absolute zz score is 0.110.11, which belongs to the papaya. / . / . / .
  12. We determine the maximum absolute zz score is 1.941.94, which belongs to the watermelon. / . / . / .

questiontext.text:
Random variable XX is normally distributed with mean μ=410\mu = 410 and standard deviation σ=20\sigma = 20. X=N(410,20)X = \text{N}(410,\,20)

Note: The answers are determined using the values from the zz-table, where probabilities are rounded to the nearest 0.0001. However, the tolerance is large enough that you can use more exact methods.

  1. Evaluate P(X<390)P(X<390). {1:NUMERICAL:=0.1587:0.004}
  2. Evaluate P(X>420)P(X>420). {1:NUMERICAL:=0.3085:0.004}
  3. Evaluate P(390<X<420)P(390 < X < 420). {1:NUMERICAL:=0.5328:0.004}

generalfeedback.text:
Find the zz scores.

z1=390−41020=−1z_1 ~=~ \frac{390-410}{20} ~=~ -1

z2=420−41020=0.5z_2 ~=~ \frac{420-410}{20} ~=~ 0.5

  1. Use the zz table to find P(Z<−1)=0.1587P(Z<-1) = 0.1587.
  2. Use the zz table, and rule of complements, to determine P(Z>0.5)=0.3085P(Z>0.5)=0.3085.
  3. Probability between two boundaries: P(−1<Z<0.5)=P(Z<0.5)−P(Z<−1)=0.5328P(-1<Z<0.5) = P(Z<0.5) - P(Z<-1) = 0.5328 Also, notice all three probabilities add to 1.

questiontext.text:
When a spinner is spun once, the probability distribution has a mean of 6.94 and standard deviation of 4.00.

That spinner will be spun 25 times, and the sum of those rolls will be recorded. What is the probability the sum will be outside 7 units from the expected value?

generalfeedback.text:
When we will sum 25 spins, the probability distribution is approximately normal, even if each spin is not normally distributed. (See Central Limit Theorem: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Central_limit_theorem .)

μ∑X=n⋅μX=(25)(6.94)=173.5\mu_{\sum X} ~=~ n\cdot \mu_X ~=~ (25)(6.94) ~=~ 173.5

σ∑X=σX⋅n=(4)⋅25=20\sigma_{\sum X} ~=~ \sigma_{X} \cdot \sqrt{n} ~=~ (4)\cdot \sqrt{25} ~=~ 20

We find a zz score. z=720=0.35z ~=~ \frac{7}{20} ~=~ 0.35

We find the probability. P(|∑X−173.5|>7)=P(|Z|>0.35)=0.7264P\left(\left|\sum X - 173.5 \right|> 7 \right) ~=~ P\left(\big|Z\big|>0.35\right) ~=~ 0.7264

In case you forgot, as long as z>0z>0, P(|Z|>z)=2−2⋅P(Z<z)P(|Z| > z) ~=~ 2-2\cdot P(Z<z)

questiontext.text:

generalfeedback.text:
When we will sum 100 spins, the probability distribution is approximately normal, even if each spin is not normally distributed. (See Central Limit Theorem: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Central_limit_theorem .)

μ∑X=n⋅μX=(100)(9.93)=993\mu_{\sum X} ~=~ n\cdot \mu_X ~=~ (100)(9.93) ~=~ 993

σ∑X=σX⋅n=(2.25)⋅100=22.5\sigma_{\sum X} ~=~ \sigma_{X} \cdot \sqrt{n} ~=~ (2.25)\cdot \sqrt{100} ~=~ 22.5

We find a zz score. z=997.5−99322.5=0.2z ~=~ \frac{997.5-993}{22.5} ~=~ 0.2

We find the probability. P(∑X>997.5)=P(Z>0.2)=0.4207P\left(\sum X > 997.5 \right) ~=~ P(Z>0.2) ~=~ 0.4207

In case you forgot, P(Z>z)=1−P(Z<z)P(Z > z) ~=~ 1 - P(Z<z)

questiontext.text:
When a spinner is spun once, the probability distribution has a mean of 6.51 and standard deviation of 5.88.

That spinner will be spun 121 times, and the sum of those rolls will be recorded. What is the probability the sum will be within 129.36 units from the expected value?

generalfeedback.text:
When we will sum 121 spins, the probability distribution is approximately normal, even if each spin is not normally distributed. (See Central Limit Theorem: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Central_limit_theorem .)

μ∑X=n⋅μX=(121)(6.51)=787.71\mu_{\sum X} ~=~ n\cdot \mu_X ~=~ (121)(6.51) ~=~ 787.71

σ∑X=σX⋅n=(5.88)⋅121=64.68\sigma_{\sum X} ~=~ \sigma_{X} \cdot \sqrt{n} ~=~ (5.88)\cdot \sqrt{121} ~=~ 64.68

We find a zz score. z=129.3664.68=2z ~=~ \frac{129.36}{64.68} ~=~ 2

We find the probability. P(|∑X−787.71|<129.36)=P(|Z|<2)=0.9544P\left(\left|\sum X - 787.71 \right|< 129.36 \right) ~=~ P\left(\big|Z\big|<2\right) ~=~ 0.9544

In case you forgot, as long as z>0z>0, P(|Z|<z)=2⋅P(Z<z)−1P(|Z| < z) ~=~ 2\cdot P(Z<z)-1

μ∑X=n⋅μX=(81)(2.91)=235.71\mu_{\sum X} ~=~ n\cdot \mu_X ~=~ (81)(2.91) ~=~ 235.71

σ∑X=σX⋅n=(2.08)⋅81=18.72\sigma_{\sum X} ~=~ \sigma_{X} \cdot \sqrt{n} ~=~ (2.08)\cdot \sqrt{81} ~=~ 18.72

We find a zz score. z=254.43−235.7118.72=1z ~=~ \frac{254.43-235.71}{18.72} ~=~ 1

We find the probability. P(∑X<254.43)=P(Z<1)=0.8413P\left(\sum X < 254.43 \right) ~=~ P(Z<1) ~=~ 0.8413

questiontext.text:
When a spinner is spun once, the probability distribution has a mean of 6.16 and standard deviation of 4.00.

That spinner will be spun 100 times, and the sum of those rolls will be recorded. What is the probability the sum will be outside 70 units from the expected value?

generalfeedback.text:
When we will sum 100 spins, the probability distribution is approximately normal, even if each spin is not normally distributed. (See Central Limit Theorem: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Central_limit_theorem .)

μ∑X=n⋅μX=(100)(6.16)=616\mu_{\sum X} ~=~ n\cdot \mu_X ~=~ (100)(6.16) ~=~ 616

σ∑X=σX⋅n=(4)⋅100=40\sigma_{\sum X} ~=~ \sigma_{X} \cdot \sqrt{n} ~=~ (4)\cdot \sqrt{100} ~=~ 40

We find a zz score. z=7040=1.75z ~=~ \frac{70}{40} ~=~ 1.75

We find the probability. P(|∑X−616|>70)=P(|Z|>1.75)=0.0802P\left(\left|\sum X - 616 \right|> 70 \right) ~=~ P\left(\big|Z\big|>1.75\right) ~=~ 0.0802

In case you forgot, as long as z>0z>0, P(|Z|>z)=2−2⋅P(Z<z)P(|Z| > z) ~=~ 2-2\cdot P(Z<z)

generalfeedback.text:
When we will average 36 spins, the probability distribution is approximately normal, even if each spin is not normally distributed. (See Central Limit Theorem: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Central_limit_theorem .)

μX‾=μX=4.25\mu_{\bar{X}} ~=~ \mu_X ~=~ 4.25

σX‾=σXn=3.636=0.6\sigma_{\bar{X}} ~=~ \frac{\sigma_{X}}{\sqrt{n}} ~=~ \frac{3.6}{\sqrt{36}} ~=~ 0.6

We find a zz score. z=0.840.6=1.4z ~=~ \frac{0.84}{0.6} ~=~ 1.4

We find the probability. P(|X‾−4.25|<0.84)=P(|Z|<1.4)=0.8384P\left(\left|\bar{X}-4.25\right| < 0.84 \right) ~=~ P(|Z|<1.4) ~=~ 0.8384

In case you forgot, as long as z>0z>0, P(|Z|<z)=2⋅P(Z<z)−1P(|Z| < z) ~=~ 2\cdot P(Z<z)-1

questiontext.text:
When a spinner is spun once, the probability distribution has a mean of 7.32 and standard deviation of 6.00.

That spinner will be spun 64 times, and the sample mean of those rolls will be recorded. What is the probability the sample mean will be between 6.36 and 8.07?

generalfeedback.text:
When we will average 64 spins, the probability distribution is approximately normal, even if each spin is not normally distributed. (See Central Limit Theorem: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Central_limit_theorem .)

μX‾=μX=7.32\mu_{\bar{X}} ~=~ \mu_X ~=~ 7.32

σX‾=σXn=664=0.75\sigma_{\bar{X}} ~=~ \frac{\sigma_{X}}{\sqrt{n}} ~=~ \frac{6}{\sqrt{64}} ~=~ 0.75

We find a zz scores. z1=6.36−7.320.75=−1.28z_1 ~=~ \frac{6.36-7.32}{0.75} ~=~ -1.28

z2=8.07−7.320.75=1z_2 ~=~ \frac{8.07-7.32}{0.75} ~=~ 1

We find the probability. P(6.36<X‾<8.07)=P(−1.28<Z<1)=0.741P\left(6.36 < \bar{X} < 8.07 \right) ~=~ P\left(-1.28 < Z < 1\right) ~=~ 0.741

In case you forgot, as long as z1<z2z_1<z_2, P(z1<Z<z2)=P(Z<z2)−P(Z<z1)P(z_1 < Z < z_2) ~=~ P(Z<z_2) - P(Z<z_1)

questiontext.text:
When a spinner is spun once, the probability distribution has a mean of 9.82 and standard deviation of 2.50.

That spinner will be spun 100 times, and the sample mean of those rolls will be recorded. What is the probability the sample mean will be more than 9.57?

generalfeedback.text:
When we will average 100 spins, the probability distribution is approximately normal, even if each spin is not normally distributed. (See Central Limit Theorem: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Central_limit_theorem .)

μX‾=μX=9.82\mu_{\bar{X}} ~=~ \mu_X ~=~ 9.82

σX‾=σXn=2.5100=0.25\sigma_{\bar{X}} ~=~ \frac{\sigma_{X}}{\sqrt{n}} ~=~ \frac{2.5}{\sqrt{100}} ~=~ 0.25

We find a zz score. z=9.57−9.820.25=−1z ~=~ \frac{9.57-9.82}{0.25} ~=~ -1

We find the probability. P(X‾>9.57)=P(Z>−1)=0.1587P\left(\bar{X} > 9.57 \right) ~=~ P(Z>-1) ~=~ 0.1587

In case you forgot, P(Z>z)=1−P(Z<z)P(Z > z) ~=~ 1 - P(Z<z)

questiontext.text:
When a spinner is spun once, the probability distribution has a mean of 9.53 and standard deviation of 6.00.

That spinner will be spun 144 times, and the sample mean of those rolls will be recorded. What is the probability the sample mean will be outside 1.08 units from the expected value?

generalfeedback.text:
When we will average 144 spins, the probability distribution is approximately normal, even if each spin is not normally distributed. (See Central Limit Theorem: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Central_limit_theorem .)

μX‾=μX=9.53\mu_{\bar{X}} ~=~ \mu_X ~=~ 9.53

σX‾=σXn=6144=0.5\sigma_{\bar{X}} ~=~ \frac{\sigma_{X}}{\sqrt{n}} ~=~ \frac{6}{\sqrt{144}} ~=~ 0.5

We find a zz score. z=1.080.5=2.16z ~=~ \frac{1.08}{0.5} ~=~ 2.16

We find the probability. P(|X‾−9.53|>1.08)=P(|Z|>2.16)=0.0308P\left(\left|\bar{X}-9.53\right| > 1.08 \right) ~=~ P(|Z|>2.16) ~=~ 0.0308

In case you forgot, as long as z>0z>0, P(|Z|>z)=2−2⋅P(Z<z)P(|Z| > z) ~=~ 2-2\cdot P(Z<z)

questiontext.text:
When a spinner is spun once, the chance of success is 0.25.

That spinner will be spun 48 times. What is the probability the number of successes will be less than 7.5?

generalfeedback.text:
Use the de Moivre-Laplace Theorem, which tells us this binomial distribution is approximately normal. Determine the parameters. μ=np=(48)(0.25)=12\mu ~=~ np ~=~ (48)(0.25) ~=~ 12 σ=np(1−p)=(48)(0.25)(0.75)=3\sigma ~=~ \sqrt{np(1-p)} ~=~ \sqrt{(48)(0.25)(0.75)} ~=~ 3

Find the zz score. z=7.5−123=−1.5z ~=~ \frac{7.5-12}{3} ~=~ -1.5

Determine the probability. P(Z<−1.5)=0.0668P(Z<-1.5) = 0.0668

That spinner will be spun 150 times. What is the probability the number of successes will be between 79.5 and 88.5?

generalfeedback.text:
Use the de Moivre-Laplace Theorem, which tells us this binomial distribution is approximately normal. Determine the parameters. μ=np=(150)(0.6)=90\mu ~=~ np ~=~ (150)(0.6) ~=~ 90 σ=np(1−p)=(150)(0.6)(0.4)=6\sigma ~=~ \sqrt{np(1-p)} ~=~ \sqrt{(150)(0.6)(0.4)} ~=~ 6

Find the zz scores. z1=79.5−906=−1.75z_1 ~=~ \frac{79.5-90}{6} ~=~ -1.75 z2=88.5−906=−0.25z_2 ~=~ \frac{88.5-90}{6} ~=~ -0.25

Determine the probability. P(−1.75<Z<−0.25)=0.3612P(-1.75<Z<-0.25) = 0.3612

In case you forgot, as long as z1<z2z_1<z_2, P(z1<Z<z2)=P(Z<z2)−P(Z<z1)P(z_1 < Z < z_2) ~=~ P(Z<z_2) - P(Z<z_1)

questiontext.text:
When a spinner is spun once, the chance of success is 0.75.

That spinner will be spun 192 times. What is the probability the number of successes will be outside 1.5 units from the expected value?

generalfeedback.text:
Use the de Moivre-Laplace Theorem, which tells us this binomial distribution is approximately normal. Determine the parameters. μ=np=(192)(0.75)=144\mu ~=~ np ~=~ (192)(0.75) ~=~ 144 σ=np(1−p)=(192)(0.75)(0.25)=6\sigma ~=~ \sqrt{np(1-p)} ~=~ \sqrt{(192)(0.75)(0.25)} ~=~ 6

Find the zz score. z=1.56=0.25z ~=~ \frac{1.5}{6} ~=~ 0.25

Determine the probability. P(|Z|<0.25)=0.8026P(|Z|<0.25) = 0.8026

In case you forgot, as long as z>0z>0, P(|Z|>z)=2−2⋅P(Z<z)P(|Z| > z) ~=~ 2-2\cdot P(Z<z)

Find the zz score. z=31.5−274.5=1z ~=~ \frac{31.5-27}{4.5} ~=~ 1

Determine the probability. P(Z>1)=0.1587P(Z>1) = 0.1587

In case you forgot, P(Z>z)=1−P(Z<z)P(Z > z) ~=~ 1 - P(Z<z)

questiontext.text:
When a spinner is spun once, the chance of success is 0.6.

That spinner will be spun 150 times. What is the probability the proportion of successes will be between 0.59 and 0.61?

generalfeedback.text:
Use the de Moivre-Laplace Theorem, which tells us this proportion-sampling distribution is approximately normal. Determine the parameters. μ=p=0.6\mu ~=~ p ~=~ 0.6 σ=p(1−p)n=(0.6)(0.4)150=0.04\sigma ~=~ \sqrt{\frac{p(1-p)}{n}} ~=~ \sqrt{\frac{(0.6)(0.4)}{150}} ~=~ 0.04

Find the zz scores. z1=0.59−0.60.04=−0.25z_1 ~=~ \frac{0.59-0.6}{0.04} ~=~ -0.25 z2=0.61−0.60.04=0.25z_2 ~=~ \frac{0.61-0.6}{0.04} ~=~ 0.25

Determine the probability. P(−0.25<Z<0.25)=0.1974P(-0.25<Z<0.25) = 0.1974

In case you forgot, as long as z1<z2z_1<z_2, P(z1<Z<z2)=P(Z<z2)−P(Z<z1)P(z_1 < Z < z_2) ~=~ P(Z<z_2) - P(Z<z_1)

generalfeedback.text:
Use the de Moivre-Laplace Theorem, which tells us this proportion-sampling distribution is approximately normal. Determine the parameters. μ=p=0.6\mu ~=~ p ~=~ 0.6 σ=p(1−p)n=(0.6)(0.4)150=0.04\sigma ~=~ \sqrt{\frac{p(1-p)}{n}} ~=~ \sqrt{\frac{(0.6)(0.4)}{150}} ~=~ 0.04

Find the zz scores. z1=0.57−0.60.04=−0.75z_1 ~=~ \frac{0.57-0.6}{0.04} ~=~ -0.75 z2=0.63−0.60.04=0.75z_2 ~=~ \frac{0.63-0.6}{0.04} ~=~ 0.75

Determine the probability. P(−0.75<Z<0.75)=0.5468P(-0.75<Z<0.75) = 0.5468

In case you forgot, as long as z1<z2z_1<z_2, P(z1<Z<z2)=P(Z<z2)−P(Z<z1)P(z_1 < Z < z_2) ~=~ P(Z<z_2) - P(Z<z_1)

That spinner will be spun 150 times. What is the probability the proportion of successes will be between 0.33 and 0.39?

generalfeedback.text:
Use the de Moivre-Laplace Theorem, which tells us this proportion-sampling distribution is approximately normal. Determine the parameters. μ=p=0.4\mu ~=~ p ~=~ 0.4 σ=p(1−p)n=(0.4)(0.6)150=0.04\sigma ~=~ \sqrt{\frac{p(1-p)}{n}} ~=~ \sqrt{\frac{(0.4)(0.6)}{150}} ~=~ 0.04

Find the zz scores. z1=0.33−0.40.04=−1.75z_1 ~=~ \frac{0.33-0.4}{0.04} ~=~ -1.75 z2=0.39−0.40.04=−0.25z_2 ~=~ \frac{0.39-0.4}{0.04} ~=~ -0.25

Determine the probability. P(−1.75<Z<−0.25)=0.3612P(-1.75<Z<-0.25) = 0.3612

In case you forgot, as long as z1<z2z_1<z_2, P(z1<Z<z2)=P(Z<z2)−P(Z<z1)P(z_1 < Z < z_2) ~=~ P(Z<z_2) - P(Z<z_1)

questiontext.text:
When a spinner is spun once, the chance of success is 0.4.

That spinner will be spun 150 times. What is the probability the proportion of successes will be outside 0.07 units from the expected value?

generalfeedback.text:
Use the de Moivre-Laplace Theorem, which tells us this proportion-sampling distribution is approximately normal. Determine the parameters. μ=p=0.4\mu ~=~ p ~=~ 0.4 σ=p(1−p)n=(0.4)(0.6)150=0.04\sigma ~=~ \sqrt{\frac{p(1-p)}{n}} ~=~ \sqrt{\frac{(0.4)(0.6)}{150}} ~=~ 0.04

Find the zz score. z=0.070.04=1.75z ~=~ \frac{0.07}{0.04} ~=~ 1.75

Determine the probability. P(|Z|>1.75)=0.0802P(|Z|>1.75) = 0.0802

In case you forgot, as long as z>0z>0, P(|Z|>z)=2−2⋅P(Z<z)P(|Z| > z) ~=~ 2-2\cdot P(Z<z)

questiontext.text:
When a spinner is spun once, the chance of success is 0.75.

That spinner will be spun 300 times. What is the probability the proportion of successes will be between 0.725 and 0.775?

generalfeedback.text:
Use the de Moivre-Laplace Theorem, which tells us this proportion-sampling distribution is approximately normal. Determine the parameters. μ=p=0.75\mu ~=~ p ~=~ 0.75 σ=p(1−p)n=(0.75)(0.25)300=0.025\sigma ~=~ \sqrt{\frac{p(1-p)}{n}} ~=~ \sqrt{\frac{(0.75)(0.25)}{300}} ~=~ 0.025

Find the zz scores. z1=0.725−0.750.025=−1z_1 ~=~ \frac{0.725-0.75}{0.025} ~=~ -1 z2=0.775−0.750.025=1z_2 ~=~ \frac{0.775-0.75}{0.025} ~=~ 1

Determine the probability. P(−1<Z<1)=0.6826P(-1<Z<1) = 0.6826

In case you forgot, as long as z1<z2z_1<z_2, P(z1<Z<z2)=P(Z<z2)−P(Z<z1)P(z_1 < Z < z_2) ~=~ P(Z<z_2) - P(Z<z_1)

questiontext.text:
Random variable XX is normally distributed with mean 9.739.73 and standard deviation 2.002.00.

Determine xx such that P(X>x)=0.0166P(X>x)=0.0166.

generalfeedback.text:
Determine the zz score that satisfies P(Z>z)=0.0166P(Z>z)=0.0166. P(Z>2.13)=0.0166P(Z>2.13) = 0.0166 So, z=2.13z=2.13.

Convert the zz score into an xx value. x=μ+zσ=9.73+(2.13)(2)=13.99\begin{aligned} x &= \mu+z\sigma \\ &= 9.73+(2.13)(2) \\ &= 13.99 \end{aligned}

So, P(X>13.99)=0.0166P(X>13.99) = 0.0166 and x=13.99x=13.99
